entry.title: Handling High-Frequency message Integration in SAP CPI with SFTP Append Mode Issues
entry.content:
Introduction

Recently we worked on a high-frequency interface using SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) to process a continuous stream of IDocs from a source system. The requirement was to map these IDocs, and send the mapped content to a target system using SFTP. All messages needed to be appended to a single file, and that file was picked up and processed by a job every 5 minutes at the target side.

At first glance, this looked like a simple scenario, but it turned out to be a tricky problem due to the way SFTP receiver works in high-frequency situations.

Problem Statement

We received a high volume of IDocs per minute, and our CPI iFlow was designed to do the following:

Map incoming IDocs to the target structure.

Use the SFTP Receiver Adapter and append to write to a single file for 5 mins after this  the downstream job process every 5 minutes. However, the target system experienced significant problems with increased load.

1. NULL characters in random lines.

2. Truncation of data.

Final file was corrupted or incomplete and therefore unusable. Final file was looking like below:

We noted the following:

The SFTP Adapter in Append Mode cannot support concurrent writes. When multiple CPI threads attempted to append concurrently:

  • Some I/O calls overlapped.
  • File locks failed.
  • The content was corrupted (e.g. NULL characters, partial lines).

CPI does not guarantee ordered or transactional writes when multiple messages are attempting to access the SFTP channel at the same time.

Solution:

To resolve the issue, we redesigned the solution as 2 separate iFlows utilizing Data Store.

iFlow 1 - Message Processing and Write to Data Store

This iFlow receives Idoc from the SAP system and after doing the map it stores the file to the DataStore.

 

Iflow step details:

  • Set header and Content: This is used to set custom header and properties required for processing and logging.
  • Message Mapping: here Idoc structure is mapped to the required target structure.
  • Write: The transformed structure is then write to the Data Store for the next step. This structure should be in XML format for the next step to read it.

iFlow 2 ‚Äì Aggregation and SFTP File Upload

This iFlow is triggered by a Timer every 5 minutes. It reads all messages stored earlier by the 1st iFlow.

  • We have used Data Store Select to fetch all unprocessed messages in the interval of 5 mins. We have given the number of messages as 500, so that it will pull all the files written by 1st flow on DataStore.

 "Delete on Completion" This check we have selected such that no file will be processed twice after successful processing of the file.

We have given the Number of polled messages as 500, so that it will pick up all the messages that were stored in datastore during last 5 mins. If any data left it will be processed in next poll.

  • When Select step is picking the file up from the data store it combines all the files in the following structure.

In my case the file was looking as below:

We have used a simple groovy to collect all the data between the tag <data> and appended them to create a CSV file

def Message processData(Message message) {
    // Get XML as string
    def body = message.getBody(String)

    // Parse XML using XmlSlurper
    def root = new XmlSlurper().parseText(body)

    // Collect all <data> elements
    def dataLines = root.message.record.data.collect { it.text() }

    // Create CSV string with LF at end
    def csv = dataLines.join("\n") + "\n"

    // Set CSV as new body
    message.setBody(csv)
    return message
}

After the groovy the file looks like as below:

This approach created the file which behaves like Append Mode but in a safe, sequential, and controlled manner.

The resulting content is then sent to the target using the SFTP Receiver Adapter.

In conclusion, this method ensures data integrity, sequential processing, and improved performance by safely simulating append mode of SFTP receiver adapter.
No concurrency issues
No file corruption
Scalable for high-volume scenarios

Thank you.

entry.title: High-Volume Data Handling in SAP Integration Suite - Our Journey to 10 Million Records
entry.content:
‚ÄúIn the middle of difficulty lies opportunity.‚Äù ‚Äì Albert Einstein

Handling large-volume data integration is something every integration specialist meets sooner or later. Recently, our team faced one of those ‚Äúopportunities‚Äù‚Äîa requirement to transfer around 10 million records from a source system to a target application using SAP Integration Suite (IS) formerly called as SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI).

At first glance, the mapping requirements were straightforward. But as always, the devil hides in the details: the pagination behavior of the OData V4 adapter, the Integration Suite processing limits, and unforeseen behavioral quirks pushed us through several attempts before landing on a robust solution.

This blog walks through:

  • What approaches we tried
  • Why they failed
  • What finally worked
  • Key learnings for anyone building high-volume integrations on SAP IS

Context: The Scenario

The source system exposed data through an OData V4 service. A key limitation we discovered early on:

  • Pagination is fully server-controlled in OData V4 adapter
  • The page size cannot be customized in SAP Integration Suite (e.g., you cannot set it to 1,000 or 10,000) when using the standard OData V4 adapter, it always respects the server-side limit
  • Example: If the server page size is 50,000, SAP IS will always retrieve chunks of 50,000 - nothing less

This limitation became the center of the problem.

Approach 1 ‚Äî Standard OData V4 Adapter + Looping Process Call

(Expected to work‚Ä¶ reality had other plans)

How it worked:

  • Used the OData V4 adapter as-is with server-side pagination
  • Used Looping Process Call to iterate through pages

What happened:

  • If the total data was below 50K, everything worked smoothly
  • Above 50K, the iFlow got stuck in Processing
  • No errors
  • No termination
  • Messages remained frozen for days

Example:

  • Server page size ‚Üí 50K
  • Data set = 40K ‚Üí Success
  • Data set = 150K ‚Üí iFlow stalled indefinitely

Lesson: Looping + uncontrolled server pagination = unpredictable behavior.

Approach 2 ‚Äî OData V4 Adapter + Custom Pagination Logic

(Better‚Ä¶ but still not scalable enough)

This time we added:

  • Custom counter checks
  • Pagination logic in iFlow
  • Looping until full completion

Result:

  • Worked better than Approach 1
  • Successfully processed volumes under ~1 million records
  • Beyond that threshold ‚Üí iFlow stuck again, still showing Processing but not progressing
  • No runtime error, no bottleneck in MPL ‚Äî simply a silent stall

Lesson: The bottleneck was structural, not logical.

Approach 3 ‚Äî Final Working Solution (and the hero of the story)

‚ÄúSimplicity is the ultimate sophistication.‚Äù ‚Äî Leonardo da Vinci

Key idea:

Avoid OData V4 adapter entirely.

Use the Classic HTTP Adapter with explicit control over pagination (via top & skip).

This allowed us to fully control the data fetch size and execution flow.

Our Winning Architecture

Flow 1: Master Controller iFlow

  1. Call the source system via HTTP adapter
  2. Retrieve total record count
  3. Calculate the required number of batches
    • Batch size = server-side max (e.g., 50K)
  4. For each batch, create a message containing only the skip value
  5. Store skip values in Data Store

Example:

Total records = 1,000,000
Batch size = 50,000
Total batches = 20
Stored skip values = 0, 50000, 100000, ...


Flow 2: Worker iFlow

  1. Poll Data Store
  2. Read skip value
  3. Call API using HTTP adapter with parameters:
    $top=50000
    $skip=<value from datastore>
  4. Process the dataset
  5. Deliver to target system

The Big Win

This mechanism:

  • Gave us full control over pagination
  • Completely bypassed OData V4 limitations
  • Handled 10+ MILLION records without stalls
  • Achieved stable throughput
  • No permanent IFlow ‚ÄúProcessing‚Äù states
  • No invisible bottlenecks

Lesson: If the adapter limits you, take control with HTTP.

Key Learnings

  • SAP Integration Suite is powerful and evolving, but very high-volume scenarios still expose adapter-level limitations
  • OData V4 Adapter may not be suitable for massive pagination-driven extractions in all cases
  • HTTP adapter with custom pagination is a reliable fallback
  • Sometimes the ‚Äúclassic‚Äù tool is the best tool

And yes‚Äîraising an SAP incident might eventually clarify the root cause, but business timelines forced us to engineer a workaround.

Conclusion

High-volume data integration is never trivial. The key is to experiment, observe system behavior, and design around limitations. Our final approach was not just functional‚Äîit was scalable, predictable, and production-proof.

If you‚Äôre dealing with similar large dataset transfers in SAP IS, this solution pattern might save you hours of troubleshooting.

Feedback Welcome

I‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts, improvements, or other patterns you‚Äôve successfully used for large-volume integration scenarios in SAP Integration Suite.

Thank you for reading!

I2Integration Solutions | A Startup

Connect in LinkedIn: I2Integrate

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite ‚Äì Cloud integration Message Usage analytics details
entry.content:
Introduction

We are excited to share the latest improvements in SAP Integration Suite designed to support key business scenarios related to consumption-based usage tracking.

With these enhancements, users can now gain deeper insights into message consumption across their integration flows and easily download consolidated monthly usage reports.

Before we dive in, you can refer to the definitions of Instance and Message in Integration Suite here:

  • Tenant definition
  • Message definition

 

How to check Cloud Integration capability consumptions as a Subaccount Admin

If you are a subaccount admin and want to know the consumption of the cloud integration capability in Integration Suite service, follow these steps:

  1. Open your subaccount where Cloud Integration capability of Integration Suite service is activated.
  2. In the left navigation pane, click on Usage Analytics. This page displays the consumption details for all services.
  3. You can select a date range (Period) to view usage for a specific timeframe.
  4. After selecting the required period, the table will show detailed consumption for all services. In the table, check the ‚ÄúService Plan‚Äù column for entries related to Integration Suite ‚Äì messages.
  5. For Cloud Integration (CPI) messages, two entries are important:
    1. Total Cloud Integration Messages (e.g., 658 messages)
    2. Excluded Cloud Integration Messages (Only SAP to SAP) (e.g., 320 messages)
  6. Total Cloud Integration (CPI) Chargeable Messages = Total Cloud Integration Messages - Excluded Cloud Integration Messages.

 

 

In case we want to cross-verify this data at each integration flow level/MPL level, we need to navigate to the Messages Usage tile and follow the below steps:

  1. Ensure your user has the required role (PI_Administrator).
  2. Navigate to Instances and Subscriptions under the Services tab.
  3. Click Go to Application.
  4. Open the Monitoring tab and select Integrations and APIs.
  5. Scroll down to find the Messages Usage tile and click it.

On initial load, it will show the data for the current month.

 

 

Background

As many of you know, the Cloud Integration capability of SAP Integration Suite already provides double-click metering details for every integration flow execution.

Based on valuable feedback from our customers, this detailed view has proven useful in:

  • Troubleshooting message volume spikes
  • Identifying specific integration flow that contributes the most in message consumption
  • Understanding how key components (such as Splitter, Retry, or SAP-to-SAP Original Content) impact billable messages

These details are crucial for transparency and cost management, as outlined in the message definition documentation.

 

What‚Äôs New

Many customers expressed the need for a monthly consolidated Excel report for each integration flow ‚Äî including package-level information.
With this new enhancement, users can now:

  • View consolidated monthly message consumption per integration flow and per package
  • Download the report directly from the Message Usage tile in a single click
  • Share usage data easily with Lines of Business (LoBs) for further analysis and discussions

 

Access the Message Usage tile explained above.

  1. Default view shows the current month.

When you open the Message Usage tile, the dashboard automatically loads data for the current month, giving you an immediate overview of your latest message consumption trends.

  1. New Enhancement ‚Äì Below the chart you will see the consolidated table

This enhanced table provides:

  • Each integration flow‚Äôs total message count, including SAP-to-SAP messages
  • The package name associated with each integration flow
    This consolidated view helps you quickly understand usage distribution across packages and identify high-volume integrations.
  1. Download the monthly consolidated report

Simply click the Download button to export the full current monthly report.

 

 

 

Now try to get the previous month‚Äôs data

We provide up to 1 year of historical data. To get the previous month‚Äôs details, follow the steps below:

  1. Select the previous month‚Äôs first and last date

Use the Select Date Range option and choose the start and end dates of the month you want to retrieve.

  1. View the refreshed consolidated table

Once the date range is applied, the table below will automatically refresh, showing the consolidated message usage for the selected month.

  1. Download the monthly consolidated data

Click the Download button to export the full month‚Äôs report.
This file can be used for internal reviews, consumption analysis, or cost-related discussions with business teams.

 

 

Advanced Settings for Better Table Control

Along with the consolidated table, we also provide an Advanced Settings option.
Using this feature, you can:

  • Sort the data based on column
  • Filter records to focus on specific integration flows or packages
  • Adjust or reorder columns to view the information in the format that best suits your analysis

These options give you more flexibility to analyse message consumption in .

 

 

Enhanced Troubleshooting

This new capability extends our existing metering feature, which already helps users:

  • Investigate message spikes
  • Drill down into detailed metering data for specific integration flows
  • Use the interactive charts to visualize data based on selected metrics

Now, with the consolidated reporting feature, you get both detailed troubleshooting views and high-level monthly summaries ‚Äî in one place.

Conclusion

Your feedback has been helpful in shaping these improvements ‚Äî and we‚Äôd love to hear more!
Please share your thoughts, experiences, or suggestions for additional insights you‚Äôd like to see in Cloud Integration Capability.

entry.title: SAP Neo Retires ‚Äì Integration Developers Must Know Before Migrating from Neo to CF
entry.content:
SAP has announced the end of maintenance for the SAP Cloud Integration Neo environment by December 31, 2028. This impacts customers running Cloud Integration on Neo and planning to move to the Cloud Foundry‚Äìbased SAP Integration Suite.

Migrating integration flows from Neo to Cloud Foundry is not a simple export/import of iflows.
Both environments differ significantly in:

  • Infrastructure
  • Adapter deployment
  • Logging & monitoring
  • Environment variables
  • APIs
  • Security materials
  • Transport & lifecycle management

This blog summarizes the key Neo vs. Cloud Foundry differences you must consider before starting your CPI migration.

1. Cloud Integration Availability: Neo vs. Cloud Foundry

Neo

  • CPI is available as a standalone product
  • Runs in SAP-managed data centers
  • Uses Neo cockpit & proprietary deployment mechanisms

Cloud Foundry

  • CPI is part of the SAP Integration Suite capability
  • Runs on hyperscalers (AWS, Azure, GCP)
  • Uses standard CF principles for scaling, service bindings, logging

üìåImportant: Some Neo features may not be available or behave differently in CF (refer to Note 2903776).

2. Adapter Deployment Differences

Neo

  • Custom adapters deployed using Eclipse plugin
  • Adapter artifacts managed in Neo cockpit

Cloud Foundry

  • Custom adapters are deployed as Integration Adapter artifacts
  • Managed via Cloud Integration Design & Monitor applications
  • Deployment uses CF-based lifecycle mechanisms

Impact:
If you have custom adapters built for Neo, they must be rebuilt or repackaged for Cloud Foundry. Here is the help document to create custom adapters Developing Customer Adapters

3. Logging Differences - Audit Logs & Access Logs

Neo

  • Audit logs retrieved via Neo Audit Log API
  • Access logs available under ‚ÄúAccess Logs‚Äù section

Cloud Foundry

  • Audit logs available through SAP Audit Log Service
  • Access logs integrated with Application Logs
  • Monitoring done via Cloud Integration Monitor

Impact:
Integrations relying on Neo-specific APIs must be redesigned for CF logging services. Here is the help document related to Audit logging in CF environment Audit Logging in CF 

4. Environment Variables - Critical Migration Topic

We can use environment variables in integration flows to address technical details like the region,port..etc where Cloud Integration is deployed.

The following table provides the mapping of environment variables in Neo and Cloud Foundry.

 

Variable Name - NeoVariable Name -CFDescription

HC_APPLICATION

Example value: abcd01iflmap

TENANT_NAME

Example value: xyz001

Sub domain of worker application (associated with application identifier for worker node)

HC_APPLICATION_URL

Example value: abcd01iflmap.uvwxy.eu1.hana.ondemand.com

TENANT_NAME + IT_SYSTEM_ID + IT_TENANT_UX_DOMAIN

Example value: xyz001.it-cpi001.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com

URL of the worker application sub domain

HC_HOST

Example value: hana.ondemand.com

IT_TENANT_UX_DOMAIN

Example value: cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com

Base URL of the SAP BTP region host where the application is deployed

HC_LOCAL_HTTP_PORT

Example value: 9001

PORT

Example value: 8080

HTTP port of the application bound to localhost

HC_OP_HTTP_PROXY_HOST

VCAP_SERVICES

Host of the HTTP Proxy for on-premise connectivity

HC_OP_HTTP_PROXY_PORT

Example value: 20003

VCAP_SERVICES

Example value: 20003

Port of the HTTP Proxy for on-premise connectivity

HC_REGION

Example value: EU_1

IT_TENANT_UX_DOMAIN

Example value: cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com

Region where the application is deployed

Here is the nice blog on how to call/get environment variable in CF Integration flows - identify-sap-cloud-integration-tenant-stage-at-runtime 

5. OData API Access Considerations

Neo

  • Uses Neo-based OAuth clients
  • API base URLs differ
  • Some OAuth grant types are Neo-specific

Cloud Foundry

  • Requires enabling API clients via XSUAA
  • Uses Integration Suite base URLs
  • Authentication flows must be updated

For example:
If you use CPI OData APIs for CI/CD, monitoring, or automation, the endpoints and tokens must be regenerated. Here is the help document gives more details on inbound communication setup - connection setup for inbound communication for api clients 

6. Transport Management & Lifecycle Changes

For the transport of integration content across different tenants, different options are available:

  • Manual export and import
  • Usage of CTS+
  • Usage of the cloud-based Transport Management

These options are identical independent of the environment (Cloud Foundry or Neo). However, setting up transport management using the cloud-based Transport Management service is different in both environments

7. Security Materials (Certificates, Keys, OAuth)

Neo

  • Keystore stored and managed directly inside Neo cockpit
  • OAuth clients created using Neo administration tools

Cloud Foundry

  • Uses Service Instances for trust stores
  • Certificates and keys must be re-imported
  • OAuth clients created via Integration Suite

Impact:
Rebuild all security configurations - especially if you use SFTP, AS2, OData, or SOAP with certificates.

8. Custom Scripting Adjustments (Groovy/JavaScript)

Some scripts refer to Neo-specific:

  • Endpoints
  • Log files
  • Environment variables
  • Adapter classes
  • Tenant metadata

These must be refactored to support CF equivalents.

9. Monitoring Experience Differences

Neo

  • Heavy reliance on Neo cockpit
  • Simplified logging UI
  • Access logs separate from application logs

CF

  • CPI Monitor in Integration Suite
  • Centralized message processing logs
  • Audit logging via SAP Audit Log Service
  • Better integrations with external monitoring tools

Impact:
Monitoring dashboards and alerting need reconfiguration.

Conclusion

Migrating SAP Cloud Integration from Neo to Cloud Foundry is a strategic, time-sensitive initiative as Neo retires in 2028. However, the migration is not a technical copy-paste.
Neo and Cloud Foundry differ significantly in:

  • Adapter deployment
  • Logging & audit mechanisms
  • Environment variables
  • OAuth & API access
  • Transport landscape
  • Runtime services
  • Security configuration

By understanding these environment-specific differences early - and adjusting integration flows, scripts, endpoints, and credentials accordingly - you can avoid migration failures, reduce manual fixes, and ensure a smooth transition to the SAP Integration Suite on Cloud Foundry.

If planned well, the Cloud Foundry environment offers:

  • Better scalability
  • CI/CD readiness
  • Modern logging and monitoring
  • Hyperscaler flexibility
  • Improved integration lifecycle governance

The best time to start preparing is now.

entry.title: How to Scale AI: The importance of modernizing data and integrating processes
entry.content:
How to Scale AI: The importance of modernizing data and integrating processes

Read the original article here

Expectations of the potential impact of AI have never been higher. But so far, most projects have only produced incremental improvements in isolated areas. So, what do you have to do to get AI to deliver material change across your business? The answer lies in preparing your processes and data‚Äîgetting them into a condition where AI can use them to deliver on its promise of radical transformation. In this thought provoking article, two AI experts from SAP explain what‚Äôs involved, where to get started, and which SAP solutions can help you really put AI to work.

About the authors:

J√ºrgen Butsmann is part of the SAP Cloud ERP Product Marketing team responsible for AI in the context of SAP S/4HANA, finance and digital supply chain. J√ºrgen has been with SAP for more than 26 years.  He is a recognized expert for SAP S/4HANA and SAP BTP .

Terry Penner is part of the SAP BTP product marketing team, focused on SAP BTP for Cloud ERP. He has more than 25 years of technical and business experience in the SAP platform and analytics, including working directly on hundreds of customer implementations and presenting on SAP technology topics at conferences around the world.

 

The challenges in reaching AI‚Äôs potential

Business leaders believe AI has the potential to transform their organizations.  They see it accelerating cycle times, reducing errors, performing processes automatically, and yielding insights. Their initial experiments and projects have reinforced this expectation by delivering productivity improvements, albeit in isolated areas.

However, return on investment has so far been disappointing and IT teams are finding it challenging to scale AI beyond point solutions. They‚Äôre also nervous for ethical and security reasons about exposing their proprietary business data to public large language  models (LLMs).

Observations from customers

The discussions we‚Äôve been having with SAP customers have revealed these common challenges IT leaders face in realizing AI‚Äôs potential.

  • Insecure architecture. Using public LLMs alone is not always reliable. AI really needs to use the organization‚Äôs own business data. But exposing corporate data to LLMs raises security and ethical issues.
  • Fragmented systems. Applying AI to a process that is contained within a single system is relatively easy. But most real business processes span multiple departments and systems. Often these applications and their data are not integrated which prevents AI from carrying out business processes end to end.
  • No single semantic layer. Enterprise applications today, whether SAP or non-SAP, all have differences in their data structures. Data transformation and harmonization are necessary to allow the sharing of transactional data, and for analytical processes and AI functions to  take place.
  • One-way data transformation. Data warehousing, as practiced by SAP and by other vendors in the past, focused on extraction  and one-way transformation, storage, and processing of data, decoupled from original data structures and business process context. Effective, enterprise-wide AI, however, requires two-way transformation and re-integration of data into business processes as they run.

What organizations need

AI agent networks need a solid data foundation  if they are to process queries across systems effectively. The organization‚Äôs data structures‚Äîits master data and system architecture‚Äîneed to be harmonized so AI can understand the different systems in a consistent and accurate way.

When processes are integrated, consistent data can be stored in the systems. Integrating systems and maintaining consistent data will overcome the problem of isolated, fragmented systems and allow AI to execute end-to-end business processes.

 

SAP‚Äôs strategy for scalable AI

SAP‚Äôs approach to enabling organizations to scale their use of AI is to facilitate the integration of systems and business processes, and the harmonization of business data, within a secure AI architecture.

The key components of this are:

  • Secure AI architecture
  • Solutions for scaling AI
  • Joule, the integrated digital assistant
  • SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) for data harmonization
  • SAP Business Technology Platform as the platform for Joule, SAP BDC, AI Hub, and process

Secure AI architecture

Figure 1: A common sub-optimal approach

Figure 2: Exposing corporate data to LLMs is not recommended

Figure 3: How to allow AI to understand your business safely

SAP's secure architecture allows AI to understand your business safely.

The process works like this:

  • The user queries their digital assistant, Joule.
  • The digital assistant uses both the LLM and the vector database to create a refined prompt. The technical process is decoupled from the proprietary business data (a technique known as masking) to prevent the data being exposed outside the organization.
  • The refined prompt then requests data from cloud ERP and other proprietary systems, such as the  SAP Foundation Model.
  • Data is returned to the digital assistant via the vector database and the results are clustered and explained by the LLM.
  • The digital assistant then presents the final answer to the user.

 

SAP solutions for scaling AI

As an SAP customer, you may be familiar with our strategic architecture. Working from the top down, we call out here three elements which are material to scaling AI.

Figure 4: SAP strategic architecture

Joule

Joule is SAP‚Äôs agent orchestrator and ubiquitous user interface for AI. It is embedded throughout SAP Business Suite solutions incl. SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Cloud ERP Private. Joule skills perform simple repetitive tasks within one application. Joule Agents give context-aware access to a system  of AI agents, that can perform more complex end-to-end processes across multiple systems‚Äî provided those systems have been integrated and their data‚Äôs been harmonized.

Agents can work within or separately from Joule. They can call and quest other agents in the background without having to be triggered manually. This is done transparently in Joule to keep the human in the loop.

SAP Business Technology Platform

SAP Business Technology Platform supports SAP Business Suite solutions. It provides a foundation for AI and data analytics and includes integration and extension solutions.

  • SAP Integration Suite contains more than 3,800 prebuilt integrations and APIs for connecting business processes across systems more easily.
  • SAP Build solutions help you create extensions and automate processes across SAP and  non-SAP solutions.

SAP Business Data Cloud

SAP Business Data Cloud provides a single semantic layer across applications and enables the harmonization of data. This is essential not only for AI to work effectively, but also to share transactional data and facilitate analytical processes. SAP BDC uses data products which are prebuilt multi-layered structures (which may include extensions of clean-core compliant data structures) for executing function-specific queries and processes across SAP and non-SAP systems.

Having a common data platform across your enterprise allows AI to utilize your proprietary  business data within a secure environment. The data products come as part of so-called intelligent applications which contains applications built using the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, as well as other domain content.

Customers can always extend the data layer, for example by defining custom data products.

Advantages of SAP Business Data Cloud

In some cases, operational data has been used for executing AI functions or analytical and planning operations without applying data products from SAP BDC. In the past, data storage for these operations took place in BTP, as the AI hub is located there as well as in SAP Datasphere and SAP HANA. But what was missing was the delivery of a common and harmonized data storage concept across all SAP applications.

SAP BDC makes it possible to establish a common architecture where data is extracted, transformed, and returned to SAP Business Suite applications, creating harmonized data storage. A common data platform across your organization will provide the data foundation for AI to connect securely to specialized, enterprise-specific data.

SAP BDC also allows for SAP-managed deployment, maintenance, and facilitation of data processing and transformation from the source system to SAP BDC. These services are part of the data products of the intelligent applications.

SAP Business Suite provides APIs between different SAP and non-SAP applications, allowing the data exchange needed for integrated execution of business processes.

Prioritizing the establishment of a common layer also influences changes to local data structures. The data required to support integrated business process and other cross-system operations is held directly within the source systems, with no need for a secondary harmonization layer. This is very well aligned with the clean core concept.

 

What does it mean for me?

Do I need all this before my AI will work?

No, but the more elements you have, the more value you get.

  • If you only have SAP BDC, you‚Äôll have access to harmonized data‚Äîbut you won‚Äôt yet have connected business processes across applications.
  • If you use SAP BTP solutions such as SAP Integration Suite and SAP Build to create integrations and extensions, you‚Äôll be able to join up business processes across applications‚Äîbut not harmonize their data.
  • If you use SAP BDC and SAP BTP solutions together, you can integrate business processes across systems and harmonize their data. A derived harmonization model is intended to be generated by the system using APIs to produce a fully integrated model for cross-system reporting and AI data usage. Then Joule Agents can use that harmonized data to orchestrate end-to-end business processes across multiple systems automatically.

Are there other ways of doing this?

Yes, but they‚Äôre not as good. Some of our customers use third party data harmonization solutions for cross-system analytical use cases.

The difference with SAP‚Äôs AI-first strategy is that it is always aware of the actual business context and reintegrates results data back into the business process. This is essential if AI agents are to make use of that data in cross-department, cross-system use cases.

SAP‚Äôs integrated suite of ERP and business applications, together with our data management solution, and our integration and extension solutions, is unique in the marketplace at present.

How can I move from isolated use cases to enterprise-wide AI?

Basically, you need to offer AI that people can trust.

To achieve trust, you need a secure AI architecture along with integrated processes and harmonized data. When you have these, people will trust the AI model. Then they‚Äôll come to view it as reliable and adopt it for day-to-day, end-to-end business processes across the organization.

 

How this approach can help you - a worked example

Automating financial close

One of the most attractive use cases for AI is to modernize a business process which occurs in every business and which, if automated, would deliver significant productivity and cost benefits. The process in question is the financial close.

It‚Äôs a classic challenge. The data required sits in multiple systems, such as ERP, CRM, tax engines, and payroll‚Äîwhich aren‚Äôt integrated. The data is also in incompatible formats. Both these mean that considerable manual work is required in extracting and reconciling the data. All of which adds up to time, cost, and stress at the end of every accounting period.

With systems integrated using SAP Integration Suite, and data harmonized using SAP Business Data Cloud, Joule Agents can be built to help perform financial close processes optimally‚Äîalways leaving knowledgeable human beings to make the final decision.

SAP‚Äôs enablers of autonomous finance can expedite financial close processes and deliver material cost savings. The Canadian energy company, Suncor, achieved a reduction of US$20,000 in month-end closing costs and a 98% reduction in time to reconcile ICT postings using SAP Business AI and SAP Build Process Automation.

Figure 5: Integration flow diagram of a connected financial close process in SAP Integration Suite.

 

How do I get started?

To summarize, our two key recommendations are to modernize your data and integrate your processes.

Modernize your data

Evolve your data strategy from using harmonized historical data extracted from business systems, to using current data generated in the process of executing business processes.

Aim to make multiple data sources accessible to AI, including a combination of business data from multiple internal systems and external data.

Integrate your processes

Move away from older integration technologies that are not cloud aware, such as process integration or process orchestration, to standardizing on SAP Integration Suite with thousands of prebuilt integrations.

Adopt a consistent method across the organization for connecting your processes so that when you build AI agents to orchestrate them across multiple systems, users get a consistent experience.

 

Immediate next steps

Ask your SAP account manager to set up a conversation with one of our enterprise architects. You can discuss where you are now, where you want to be, and draw up a plan for getting there.

In the meantime, find out more about:

  • SAP Business Technology Platform
  • SAP Integration Suite and SAP Build
  • SAP Business Data Cloud
  • SAP‚Äôs vision for autonomous finance

entry.title: When Large XML Breaks SOAP in SAP CPI: Understanding CXF Limits, Misleading Errors, and the Real Fix
entry.content:
Prerequisites:

Recently we faced an issue: a large EPCIS payload caused CPI‚Äôs SOAP Adapter to crash with pretty technical error text:

Error Details
org.apache.camel.InvalidPayloadException: No body available of type: java.lang.String but has value: org.apache.camel.component.cxf.converter.CachedCxfPayload@22fcc44c of type: org.apache.camel.component.cxf.converter.CachedCxfPayload on: Message. Caused by: Error during type conversion from type: org.apache.camel.component.cxf.converter.CachedCxfPayload to the required type: java.lang.String with value org.apache.camel.component.cxf.converter.CachedCxfPayload@22fcc44c due to java.lang.IllegalStateException: Current event not START_ELEMENT or END_ELEMENT. Exchange[69E7F6624A5A223-000000000000000A]. Caused by: [org.apache.camel.TypeConversionException - Error during type conversion from type: org.apache.camel.component.cxf.converter.CachedCxfPayload to the required type: java.lang.String with value org.apache.camel.component.cxf.converter.CachedCxfPayload@22fcc44c due to java.lang.IllegalStateException: Current event not START_ELEMENT or END_ELEMENT], cause: java.lang.IllegalStateExcept...

Nothing in this exception suggests ‚Äúyour XML is too big‚Äù and the message was only 10M which is below default 40M SOAP Adapter max.

The Real Cause: Apache CXF XML Security Limits

CPI‚Äôs SOAP Adapter is built on Apache CXF and Apache Camel.
Before CPI ever sees the message, CXF enforces several safety thresholds:

Our EPCIS messages contained more than 100K child elements ‚Äî far beyond the 50,000 limit.

Once CXF hits a threshold, it stops parsing.
Camel then tries to convert an incomplete payload into a String or DOM ‚Äî and fails with a meaningless type-conversion exception.

Why You Cannot ‚ÄúFix the XML‚Äù

In many regulatory or B2B integrations, the message structure is dictated by standards.
In this case, reducing batch size or restructuring XML was not feasible:
the EPCIS payloads legitimately exceeded CXF‚Äôs defaults.

So we raised an SAP ticket.

SAP‚Äôs Proposed Solution

SAP confirmed the issue and outlined the steps needed to resolve it:

  1. Provide your CPI/Integration Suite tenant URL. SAP adjusts parameters at the tenant runtime level.
  2. Specify the new maxChildElements limit. Choose a value based on your maximal observed EPCIS batch size.
  3. Approve a maintenance window for restart. SAP must restart your tenant‚Äôs processing node to activate new CXF settings. Downtime: 15‚Äì20 minutes.

üí°Why a Tenant Restart Is Required ‚Äî Even in a CI/CD Cloud

This is a common point of confusion.

CPI feels like a CI/CD-managed cloud service, so why does SAP need a restart? Here‚Äôs the reason in simple terms:

CPI is cloud-hosted, but each tenant still runs on Java/Camel runtimes.

When SAP changes CXF parser limits, they are modifying JVM-level runtime properties that Camel and CXF read only at startup.

Just like changing JVM memory parameters, thread pools, or parser configurations:
these cannot be hot-reloaded.

So the restart isn‚Äôt a flaw ‚Äî it‚Äôs a consequence of:

  • the underlying Java processes
  • Camel routing engines
  • CXF parser initialisation

It is normal and expected behaviour

‚úîÔ∏èKey Takeaways

  • CPI SOAP Adapter errors can be misleading when XML is too large.
  • The real limits come from Apache CXF, not SAP configuration mistakes.
  • EPCIS and similar standards may exceed maxChildElements.
  • XML cannot always be made smaller ‚Äî sometimes the standard dictates structure.
  • SAP can raise limits, but must restart the tenant to apply changes.

entry.title: Migrating XSLT mappings from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
This blog post is part of the series Master Blog: SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite Migration ‚Äì Tool and Guidance exploring how to migrate various integration patterns from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite using the Migration Tool. In this blog, we will explore the migration process of XSLT mappings.   

While SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration supports XSLT mappings, you may encounter subtle yet impactful differences when migrating XSLT-based mappings from SAP Process Orchestration (PO). This post outlines the main variations between both environments, explains typical runtime issues, and provides practical guidance for smooth adaptation.

 

XSLT Processor Differences 

The XSLT processor behind Cloud Integration is Saxon EE 9.9.1.6 (as of November 2025 ‚Äì see this Blog for details on verifying the processor version) while SAP Process Orchestration next to its default allowed the import and use of other processors. 

While these differences should not usually cause major compatibility problems, certain manual adjustments after the tool-assisted migration might be required to deploy or execute mappings successfully. In particular, there are variations in how standard XSLT functions handle data types, how Java classes are used within XSLT code and how other stylesheets are included. 

 

Data Type Handling in XSLT Functions 

SAP Process Orchestration tends to be more lenient regarding data type usage in standard XSLT functions. Cloud Integration, on the other hand, applies stricter type validation during compilation and runtime. 

Example 1: Using xsl:sort with Data Types 

The xsl:sort function sorts data based on specified criteria: 

<xsl:sort select="data" data-type="text"/> 

The allowed data types for this function are "text" and "number". On SAP Process Orchestration, the following syntax works without error: 

<xsl:sort select="DATES" order="ascending" data-type="xsd:Date"/> 

However, in Cloud Integration this causes a runtime error: 

Adjusting the data-type accordingly to text or number solves this issue. However, one needs to pay attention to the effects this might have on the format and thus the rest of the stylesheet execution. 

 

Example 2: Using format-number() with non-numeric inputs 

On SAP Process Orchestration, the following syntax works without error: 

<xsl:value-of select="format-number(substring(data, 0, 3), '0.00')"/> 

In Cloud Integration, this causes a compilation error during runtime: 

The issue arises because format-number() requires a numeric input, while substring() returns a string. 
To resolve this, explicitly convert the substring to a number: 

<xsl:value-of select="format-number(number(substring(data, 0, 3)), '0.00')"/> 

Please note that if a global number format is defined, this conversion might affect the formatting of the substring according to that global setting. 

 

Using Java Classes in XSLT 

XSLT mappings sometimes rely on custom Java classes to extend the functionality of native XSLT functions, a common practice in integration projects where XSLT offered fewer built-in capabilities.  

During migration, you may encounter Java classes ranging from simple helpers (e.g., string or date transformations, counters) to more complex ones (e.g., document loaders, RFC calls, or value mapping lookups). While some advanced use cases may require redesign or alternative approaches, simpler helper classes can still be used in Cloud Integration. 

Step 1: Uploading the Java Classes 

Upload the Java classes as a JAR file and add them to the iFlow‚Äôs References (using the Archive option). 

If the java classes are contained in the same Imported Archive (IA) as the XSLT using them on PO, the migration tool will automatically import them as it imports the entire IA during the migration process. However, if the java classes are in a separate IA, this needs to be done manually post tool migration. 

Please note that the JAR file must be added as a local resource into the iFlow. Currently it‚Äôs not possible to use as a reusable artifact. 

Step 2: Adjusting XSLT Syntax 

 

  1. Namespace Declarations 

SAP Process Orchestration allows multiple styles for Java namespace declarations, while Saxon (the processor in Cloud Integration) supports only one format. 

  1. a) Inline Declaration 

xmlns:java="http://xml.apache.org/xslt/java" 

<xsl:variable name="date" select="java:com.edi.xslthelper.DateTransform.GetDate(data)"/> 

  1. b) Namespace Declaration with Class Path 

xmlns:date="java:com.edi.xslthelper.DateTransform" 

<xsl:variable name="date" select="date:GetDate(data)"/> 

In Cloud Integration, only the second option (namespace declaration with class path) is supported. Therefore, all Java class calls must be manually adapted accordingly. 

 

  1. Type Handling in Java Class Calls 

Just like native XSLT functions, Java class calls in Cloud Integration require explicit type consistency. For example: 

<xsl:variable name="__function4" select="variable:setValue($var,'Name',string(number(data)))"/> 

If a Java class expects a string, the input must be explicitly converted. On SAP Process Orchestration, the same code might work without this conversion. 

In one specific migration case, a Java method required an integer input ‚Äî here, neither round() nor number() worked, but the XSLT function xs:integer() was necessary. 
 

Please note that compilation errors such as ‚ÄúErrors were reported during stylesheet compilation‚Äù are often related to incorrect data types. Explicitly converting inputs usually resolves these issues. 

 

References to other stylesheets within the XSLT 

XSLT code from different stylesheets can be used in an XSLT mapping using the include function: 

<xsl:include href="Stylesheet2.xsl"/> 

The included stylesheet needs to be added manually as a reference to the iflow: 

On Cloud Integration, no folder structures are supported so if the IA on PO had a nested folder structure containing the stylesheets, make sure to upload them individually and remove the path in the include function of your original stylesheet like our example above. 

 

Recommendations for Successful Migration 

To ensure smooth execution of XSLT mappings in Cloud Integration: 

  • Always verify and explicitly define correct data types. 
  • Adapt namespace declarations for all Java class calls. 
  • Adapt the include of additional stylesheets. 
  • Upload all necessary additional components (jar files, stylesheets). 
  • Test mappings individually after migration to detect type-related issues early. 
  • Simplify or refactor complex Java-dependent logic where possible. 

Following these guidelines helps prevent runtime errors and ensures stable, predictable execution after migration. 

 

Conclusion and Next Steps 

Migrating XSLT mappings from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite requires close attention to how the underlying XSLT processor interprets data types and Java extensions. 
While most mappings migrate seamlessly, subtle differences, particularly in data type handling, namespace declarations, and custom Java integrations, may lead to compilation or runtime issues if not adjusted. 

Stay tuned for the next part of this series, where we‚Äôll continue our deep dive into migration patterns and modernization best practices in SAP Integration Suite, including insights on content-based routing, custom code handling, and error management.

entry.title: SAP Cloud Integration - Upgrade Readiness Design Guidelines/Best Practices for Future Readiness
entry.content:
Introduction

Have you ever wondered where to start to understand the benefits of upgrade readiness design guidelines for your cloud integration system and how to achieve them? Then this blog post is for you! It brings you in-depth insights into the upgrade readiness concept and its implementation, with resources to help make your integration artifacts, prominently Groovy scripts, future-proof.

Whether you're developing integration scenarios in SAP Integration Suite or refining existing ones, this is your guide to ensuring long-term stability, maintainability, and resilience - even in the face of major runtime upgrades.

In this blog post, you will understand the detailed aspects of upgrade readiness, its objectives, principles and how to leverage in the integration flow tooling. With the 7.45 version in NEO and 6.72/8.36 in Cloud foundry release,  SAP Cloud Integration provides a upgrade readiness feature.

Why is Upgrade Readiness Essential?

One of the most powerful features of SAP Cloud Integration is the Groovy flow step, which allows developers to write custom Groovy scripts to solve complex problems efficiently. However, these scripts can create risks for future upgrades, especially when they rely on:

  • Unsupported system classes.
  • Internal Apache Camel framework classes.
  • Undocumented Java libraries.

Using these internal or unsupported classes may not only result in incompatibility during major runtime upgrades but can make the system fragile and prone to failures, something many of you may have experienced during previous major version upgrades.

What is Upgrade Readiness?

Upgrade readiness is a set of best practices, guidelines, rules, or tools designed to ensure scripts are clean, consistent, and ready for future upgrades. It promotes a development approach that helps maintain the stability and reliability of integration artifacts and minimizes the risk of breakdown during major runtime version upgrades in SAP Integration Suite.

Here‚Äôs how upgrade readiness can help:

  1. Restrict Usage of Internal APIs: Avoid APIs that are unsupported or pose risks during upgrades.
  2. Identify Violations in Groovy Scripts: Detect and fix problematic script patterns, such as unused imports or usage of internal APIs.
  3. Encourage Using Recommended Libraries and Standards: Build scripts that align with SAP's recommended practices and approved APIs.

Upgrade Readiness Guidelines

Adhering to these guidelines promotes a robust, scalable architecture that withstands future system upgrades. Let‚Äôs explore key considerations.

Remove Unused Imports

Unused imports create unnecessary complications during software or runtime upgrades:

  • Avoid compilation/runtime errors: Unused imports might reference deprecated libraries or classes, potentially breaking the script.
  • Eliminate visual clutter: It helps streamline script functionality while avoiding confusion about dependencies.

Best Practice: Scan all Groovy scripts for unused imports and remove them to ensure clean and efficient code.

Use Recommended Libraries and Classes

A crucial step in creating upgrade-ready artifacts is using only recommended or SAP-approved libraries and APIs:

  • Avoid Internal Classes: Replace direct usage of internal classes (e.g., Apache Camel) with SAP-provided APIs and extensions.
  • Leverage supported libraries: Always rely on SAP APIs for safe system interactions, reducing risks from dependency issues during updates.
  • Bundle custom libraries carefully: If a critical library isn‚Äôt provided by SAP, include it as part of your integration flow. However, be aware that this may impact flow size and startup performance.
  • Restrict OS/Network access: Avoid direct file/system operations; use alternatives provided by SAP.

Examples of unsupported classes to avoid:

  • System.exit() or TimeZone.setDefault()
  • Direct access to environment variables using System.getenv() or System.getProperty()
  • Console outputs like System.out.println()

Instead, use alternatives like SAP API com.sap.it.script.system.Properties for environment-safe interactions.

Refer KBA to know the list of incompatible internal classes.

Plan Proactive Cleanup of Existing Scripts

As part of preparing your system for future upgrades, ensure current scripts are compliant with upgrade readiness guidelines.

  • Start cleanup processes for existing artifacts adhering to the new framework.
  • Focus on creating awareness among development teams about unsupported script patterns.
  • Get familiar with the upgrade readiness toolset in SAP Integration Suite.

Upgrade Readiness Objectives and Strategy

Upgrade readiness is more than just avoiding future system breakdowns; it‚Äôs about establishing a future-proof integration development model.

Objectives:

  1. Enable future proofing: Build robust integration artifacts that are immune to frequent version upgrades.
  2. Ensure maintainability: Maintain clean, stable, and compatible integration scripts.
  3. Reduce upgrade risks: Proactively address dependencies on unsupported libraries and APIs.

Strategy:

  • Introduce upgrade compliance guidelines for current SAP Cloud Integration stacks (NEO, CF) to foster awareness.
  • Collaborate with teams to initiate self-service cleanup of existing artifacts.
  • Provide training and resources to ensure developers are well-versed in upgraded best practices.

Upgrade Readiness Principles

  1. Code Cleanliness

    • Remove unused imports.
    • Write concise, maintainable scripts.

  2. Avoid Unsupported APIs and Classes

    • Avoid internal, deprecated, or system-level APIs.
    • Refrain from direct OS manipulations.

  3. Use Recommended Libraries and APIs

    • Use SAP-provided or approved APIs.
    • Replace unsupported libraries with standard alternatives.

  4. Plan for Future Compatibility

    • Design artifacts resilient to runtime upgrades.
    • Ensure compatibility with future software updates.

  5. Reduce Code and Visual Clutter

    • Eliminate unnecessary logs and code blocks.
    • Keep scripts streamlined and easy to understand.

  6. Enable Proactive Cleanup

    • Regularly review and update integration artifacts.
    • Clean up older stacks like NEO and CF deployments.

  7. Avoid Operating System Manipulations

    • Avoid direct OS interactions.
    • Use platform-provided APIs for secure operations.

  8. Train Teams on Best Practices

    • Educate developers on best practices.
    • Promote awareness of upgrade readiness tools.

  9. Utilize Upgrade Readiness Tools

    • Use tools to monitor for violations.
    • Proactively identify and resolve issues.

Implementing these principles ensures stable, future-proof integration artifacts.

Steps to Apply Upgrade Readiness

Applying upgrade readiness and future-proofing your integration artifacts involves following a set of best practices and utilizing the tools provided within the integration platform. Below, we outline the steps to achieve this:

Access Integration Settings Page

    • Navigate to the Integration Settings page.
    • Here, you will find the newly introduced upgrade readiness design guidelines, which are activated by default

Open Integration Flow Editor

    • Access the integration flow editor where you design and manage your integration artifacts.
    • You will notice the same set of upgrade readiness design guidelines applicable here.

Execute Guidelines and Check Compliance Status

    • Execute the guidelines to see the compliance status of your integration artifacts.
    • Specifically check for non-compliant Groovy flow steps. Analysis feature will show the list of affected groovy scripts. Check the version of the groovy script as well.

Open the Script Editor

    • Open the script editor to examine the issues highlighted in the problems view.
    • Note that upgrading to Groovy step 2.x can fix crucial violations related to internal Camel and stack class usage.

 


Apply Fixes and Recommendations

    • Follow the suggested fixes and recommendations to make your Groovy scripts future-ready.
    • Save the Groovy script by clicking Apply and then close the editor to return to the integration flow editor.

 

Save the Integration Flow

    • Save your integration flow to ensure that all changes are persisted.
    • Verify the version of the Groovy flow step is updated to 2.x.

Re-evaluate Compliance

    • After applying the upgrades, execute the guidelines again to ensure that the previously violated Groovy steps are now compliant.

Important Note

  • You can leverage the public OData Remote APIs to read, execute and download the guidelines at the integration flow artifact level. This will promote the automation.
  • Refer to the documentation for details: Integration Flow Design Guidelines.

Why Groovy Script 2.x?

Upgrading to Groovy script 2.x provides several benefits:

  • Future-Ready Scripts: Automatic fixes for incompatible libraries and classes prepare your scripts for future major version runtime and software upgrades.
  • Advanced Groovy Features: Utilizes Groovy runtime 4.0.26, providing access to modern language elements such as switch expressions and other capabilities. You can refer the groovy 4.0.26 for more details.

Handling Non-Compatibility

If the updated version of the Groovy step does not yield the expected result then take the below measures.

  1. Downgrade Groovy Script: You can downgrade the Groovy script step and revert to the older version.
  2. Create a ServiceNow ticket : Document the issue and create a ticket using the component LOD-HCI-PI-WT-IFL for further assistance. Issue will be fixed as per the SLA.
  3. Adapt Processes: Adapt your business processes to accommodate the upgraded script to stay prepared for future upgrades. You should strive to be on the major version of the script step.

By following these steps, you can ensure that your integration artifacts are compliant with the latest guidelines and ready for future upgrades.

What‚Äôs coming next

  • Upgrade Readiness Guidelines for JavaScript.
  • Execute Design Guidelines Automatically on Artifact Save.
  • Block Artifact Deployment if Guidelines Are Violated, Governed by Tenant Administrator.
  • Central Dashboard Displaying All Incompatible Scripts at Tenant Level.

Share your feedback in the comment section on these upcoming innovations and provide your remarks on the prioritization.

I hope you find the enhancements in this blog post beneficial. If you have any questions or feedback, please leave a comment.
